sen.j: ククノチ（クグノチとも）は、日本神話に登場する木の神 (神道)である。
sen.e: "Kukunochi" (Kugunochi) is a god of trees (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.
"Kukunochi" (Kugunochi) is a god of trees (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.
"Kukunochi" (Kugunochi) is a god of trees (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

sen.j: 古事記では久久能智神、日本書紀では句句廼馳と表記する。
sen.e: It is written 久久能智神 in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters), and 句句廼馳 in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).
It is written 久久能智神 in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters), and 句句廼馳 in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).
It is written 久久能智神 in Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), and 句句廼馳 in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 神産みにおいて、イザナギ・イザナミの間に産まれた神である。
sen.e: It was a god born between Izanagi and Izanami during kamiumi (birth of the gods).
It was a god born between Izanagi and Izanami during kamiumi (birth of the gods).
It was a god born between Izanagi and Izanami during kamiumi (birth of the gods).

sen.j: 古事記においてはその次に山の神オオヤマツミ（オオヤマツミ）、野の神カヤノヒメ（カヤノヒメ）が産まれている。
sen.e: In Kojiki, mountain god, Oyamatsumi and field god, Kayano-hime, were born after this.
In Kojiki, mountain god, Oyamatsumi and field god, Kayano-hime, were born after this.
In Kojiki, god of mountains, Oyamatsumi and god of fields, Kayano-hime, were born after this.
sen.cmt: 「mountain god」→「god of mountains」「field god」→「god of fields」表現形式を統一しました。

sen.j: 日本書紀の本文では山・川・海の次に「木の精ククノチ」として産まれており、その次に草の精・野の精の草野姫（カヤノヒメ）が産まれている。
sen.e: In the main body of Nihonshoki, it was born as 'Kukunochi, the spirit of trees' after mountain, river, and sea, and after that, Kayano-hime, the spirit of grass and spirit of field was born.
In the main body of Nihonshoki, it was born as 'Kukunochi, the spirit of trees' after mountain, river, and sea, and after that, Kayano-hime, the spirit of grass and spirit of field was born.
In the main body of Nihonshoki, it was born as 'Kukunochi, the spirit of trees' after mountain, river, and sea, and after that, Kayano-hime, the spirit of grass and spirit of field was born.

sen.j: 第六の一書では「木の神たちを句句廼馳という」と記述され、木の神々の総称となっている。
sen.e: In the sixth "alternate writing," it is written 'gods of trees are called Kukunochi no kami,' and is considered the generic name for gods of trees.
In the sixth "alternate writing," it is written 'gods of trees are called Kukunochi no kami,' and is considered the generic name for gods of trees.
In the sixth "alternate writing," it is written 'gods of trees are called Kukunochi no kami,' and is considered the generic name for gods of trees.

sen.j: 神名の「クク」は、茎と同根で木が真っ直に立ち伸びる様を形容する言葉とも、木木（キキ・キギ）が転じてクク・クグになったものともいう。
sen.e: Kuku' in the shinmei (name of god) is believed to be of the same root as kuki (stem), and is a word describing the way trees grow straight up, or trees (kiki, kigi) changed to kuku, kugu.
Kuku' in the shinmei (name of god) is believed to be of the same root as kuki (stem), and is a word describing the way trees grow straight up, or trees (kiki, kigi) changed to kuku, kugu.
Kuku' in the shinmei (name of god) is believed to be of the same root as kuki (stem), and is a word describing the way trees grow straight up, or trees (kiki, kigi) changed to kuku, kugu.

sen.j: 「ノ」は助詞の「の」、「チ」はカグツチなどと同じく神霊を意味する接尾詞であるので、「ククノチ」は「茎の神」「木の神」という意味になる。
sen.e: No' is the particle 'no,' and 'chi' is a suffix meaning divine spirit, as in Kagutsuchi, so 'Kukunochi' means 'god of stem,' 'god of trees.'
No' is the particle 'no,' and 'chi' is a suffix meaning divine spirit, as in Kagutsuchi, so 'Kukunochi' means 'god of stem,' 'god of trees.'
No' is the particle 'no,' and 'chi' is a suffix meaning divine spirit, as in Kagutsuchi, so 'Kukunochi' means 'god of stem,' 'god of trees.'

sen.j: 公智神社（兵庫県西宮市）の主祭神になっているほか、久久比神社（兵庫県豊岡市）には全国唯一のコウノトリ伝説のある神社もある。
sen.e: It is the shusaijin (main enshrined deity) of Kuchi-jinja Shrine (Nishinomiya City, Hyogo Prefecture), and Kukuhi-jinja Shrine (Toyooka City, Hyogo Prefecture) has the only shrine in the country known for the stork legend.

It is the shusaijin (main enshrined deity) of Kuchi-jinja Shrine (Nishinomiya City, Hyogo Prefecture), and Kukuhi-jinja Shrine (Toyooka City, Hyogo Prefecture) has the only shrine in the country known for the stork legend.

It is the shusaijin (main enshrined deity) of Kuchi-jinja Shrine (Nishinomiya City, Hyogo Prefecture), and Kukuhi-jinja Shrine (Toyooka City, Hyogo Prefecture) has the only shrine in the country known for the stork legend.

sen.j: 木魂神社という名のククノチ神を祭る神社も複数ある。
sen.e: There are multiple shrines called Kimusubi-jinja Shrine, enshrining the Kukunochi god.
There are multiple shrines called Kimusubi-jinja Shrine, enshrining the Kukunochi god.
There are multiple shrines called Kimusubi-jinja Shrine, enshrining the Kukunochi god.

sen.j: 樽前山神社（北海道苫小牧市）では原野の神・開拓の神として大山津見神・鹿屋野比売神とともに祀られている。
sen.e: At Tarumaezan-jinja Shrine (Tomakomai City, Hokkaido), it is enshrined with Oyamatsumi-no-kami and Kayano-hime as the god of the wilds (a field) and the god of reclamation.
At Tarumaezan-jinja Shrine (Tomakomai City, Hokkaido), it is enshrined with Oyamatsumi-no-kami and Kayano-hime as the god of the wilds (a field) and the god of reclamation.
At Tarumaezan-jinja Shrine (Tomakomai City, Hokkaido), it is enshrined with Oyamatsumi-no-kami and Kayano-hime as the god of the wilds (a field) and the god of reclamation.

sen.j: 延喜式祝詞には屋船久久遅命（やふねくくのちのみこと）の名が見え、ククノチと同神と見られる。
sen.e: In the 'Norito' (Shinto prayer) of "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), there is the name of Yafunekukunochi-no-mikoto, and is believed to be the same god as Kukunochi.
sen.cmt: 「延喜式祝詞」はウェブでは『延喜式』「祝詞」となっていたため、こちらを訳出しました。
sen.e: In the 'Norito' (Shinto prayer) of "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), there is the name of Yafunekukunochi-no-mikoto, and is believed to be the same god as Kukunochi.

In the 'Norito' (Shinto prayer) of "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), there is the name of Yafunekukunochi-no-mikoto, and is believed to be the same god as Kukunochi.

sen.j: 屋船久久遅命は上棟式の祭神の一つとされている。
sen.e: Yafunekukunochi-no-mikoto is considered to be one of the enshrined deities of Jotoshiki (the roof-laying ceremony).
Yafunekukunochi-no-mikoto is considered to be one of the enshrined deities of Jotoshiki (the roof-laying ceremony).
